message_1:
Here's a precise numerical problem on Modal Logic for a math student to solve:

Suppose that the proposition P is true in all possible worlds in a modal system S, and that Q is true in only one possible world. Determine whether the following statements are true or false in S:

1. P ∧ ¬Q is possible
2. P → ◊Q is possible

Note: ◊ represents modal operator for possibility or "diamond".
message_2:
1. P ∧ ¬Q is possible

Since P is true in all possible worlds and Q is true in only one possible world, there must exist at least one possible world where Q is false. In that world, ¬Q is true. Therefore, in that world, P ∧ ¬Q is true, which means P ∧ ¬Q is possible. So, the first statement is true.

2. P → ◊Q is possible

P is true in all possible worlds, and Q is true in at least one possible world. Since Q is true in at least one possible world, ◊Q is true (because ◊Q means that Q is possible). Therefore, in all possible worlds, P → ◊Q is true, which means P → ◊Q is possible. So, the second statement is also true.
